section.text: Hey, good morning. Thanks for taking the question. First one I had is on the Commercial underlying loss ratio, just on the year-over-year comparison. I think even adjusting for some of the non-CAT items that you mentioned. It didn't improve all that much, I think it even deteriorated a touch and I just wanted to see if you could unpack what's some of the drivers are. I think there was some mention of workers' comp in the 10-Q is at least a partial drivers. So I was just looking to see if you could add some color around how we should think through the year-over-year comparisons there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Scott", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "0fed7353-7da1-4bce-85ab-1bb1b9e86475", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Thanks, Alex, I'll start and I'll let Doug provide some additional cover. So first I just -- Doug said this in his comments and I think it's always important when we start a conversation on small Commercial is by any measure, I think their results are outstanding. As Doug discussed, we did see some impact from property losses, non-CAT, non-weather related that obviously impacted that compare year-over-year, but when we look at year-to-date where we are compared to what we thought at the beginning of the year, we are right in line. As it relates specifically to the workers' compensation point, again if you go back to what we were expecting from the beginning of the year, we're very much right in line. We did not make any changes in the quarter as it relates to workers' comp and our loss picks from where we've been from the beginning of this year and we had said at the beginning of this year that in this line, we expected a small amount of compression in workers' comp and that's exactly what we've been booking to. And I say small, less than 0.5 point, part of that compared to last third quarter and why that was called out was in the last year's third quarter, we had some true-ups in the quarter related to just some favorable frequency and rate coming in a bit higher than we had anticipated. So, it's really more about last third quarter, this year and what we're producing overall completely in line with what our expectations were and no changes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "4513a46a-048c-4e4c-92ba-a0990c35b48f", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Got it. Thanks for that and maybe just a more broad question with my second. I think we've heard a couple of your peers discuss standard lines becoming a bit more competitive and I think another was commenting on casualty pricing, needing to reaccelerate and sort of highlighting the economic exposure, potentially beginning to decline and being less of a tailwind. Could you frame for us the way you're thinking about the competitive environment and pricing and where you see meeting to happen on the casualty and property side from here?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Scott", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "0ff1698a-4d1e-413b-a850-10486ce510a9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Alex. I would start by saying that we look at overall performance and we feel very positive about what we produce for nine months and look at our position in the quarter and just very pleased about that performance level. Now given the challenges that we all face, as I commented in my script, we're very conscious of both social and economic pressure inside our loss trends and we are watching them carefully across all our lines -- across all our segments. The other thing I'd say is we're coming off a significant, natural peril disaster in the southeast part of the country. So we expect that the property market will go through some changes in the coming quarters, starting very shortly. So we're in-market with our CAT reinsurance program that renews one-on-one. Our focus have been in for at all we can expect over the next several weeks that we will talk about the structure. I do not expect anything material to change relative to our reinsurance structure, but I think between property and social and economic changes, it's a really critical time you stay on-top of your trends and we're trying to do exactly that here at the Hartford.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "37c3cd8b-7087-4e0d-bab7-dc4f61cf6e0f", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Got it. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alex Scott", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "1a0ac741-8aa2-4dd4-a21d-aa41f6bd3bc0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Thanks, good morning. I wanted to go back to the commercial discussion, right? So you guys just a bit above the full-year guidance year-to-date. I know there is moving pieces and, when I say bit quite of 10 basis-points, you -- given the Q4, I think seasonally does tend to run better than some of the other quarters. Would you expect them to be within that guided range for the full-year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "1d6afbe0-0383-4fbc-84ce-922ebd07d21c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Elyse, we do. So we're expecting to hit guidance. You're right. There is seasonality in our book of business and so we're mindful of that, but based on what we see today and the early start with October -- very early start of October, we expect to be in that range.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "4b52f342-48d2-448f-826d-a5ef4302b8ad", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, thanks. And then my second question on -- it's on the Group Benefits business. Chris, I think you mentioned some higher expenses there, but if I look at the core margin excluding COVID, that was nearly 9% in the quarter versus the 6% to 7% target and you mentioned long-term disability trends are stable. So if we think about the run-rate of that Group Benefits business ex-COVID, do you think you guys could exceed that 6% to 7% target margin?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "b4ed4f7f-8b43-498b-91bd-321229c464d6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Elyse, you focused on forward guidance. And we've obviously talked about what we think we could do, but I would just share with you, yeah, we feel-good with that. The overall performance of all our businesses really through the first-nine months and that's why I sort of called that out. Investment results have been very favorable but across our portfolios, particularly with the strong LP contributions, but rates are rising. So we still like our long-term view of 6 to 7 and sort of a normalized basis if you're going to look at it that way. But, we'll always continue to try to outperform and exceed expectations. But I still would have you anchor in that 6 to 7 range.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "b73339c5-d399-4bef-855c-98f6116d1133", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, thanks for the color.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Elyse Greenspan", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "a5d51d8e-5c03-41e5-97d4-5c49f4f805ef", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Hi, thanks. Good morning. Chris and Doug, you both mentioned that you have approximately 100 basis-points of spread between renewal written pricing and loss trends. If we exclude workers' comp, just wondering what that is if we include workers' comp given how big that is within the commercial lines business?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "173ecfb9-223f-4fcc-b865-c8f2d343cf4b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yeah, I'll just reinforce what Beth said, David, is that going into the year, our pricing plan compared to what we thought loss trend was going to have modest negative effect, probably to a half a point on sort of combined ratios. I think through the first-nine months, we were outperforming with that 0.5 point negative pressure. But that's the way I would frame it and Doug, I don't know if you would add anything else, but I'd like to just have you think of comps and its own different sort of sphere as far as historical performance and the regulatory oversight in that line, David, and that's why we just talked about it ex-comp spread.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "3cd885ce-be79-47fc-8821-a6f3e1366214", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: David. I would just add that even inclusive of comp, our total commercial spread is still about the same so the calculus is plus or minus 100 points. And yes to Chris' point, comp continues to perform for us across our markets.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "2209f83e-9d15-4263-be5a-566a70980954", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, great. Thanks. That's helpful. And then also just a followup for Beth. Beth, you had said that there were some true-ups in the third quarter of 2021 related to favorable frequency and rate coming in a bit better than you had anticipated. I was wondering if you could just size the favorable impact that that had on the third quarter of 2021 in Commercial Lines.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "2a1e85ad-e2bd-4d87-90ca-7664166c4021", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yes, so I guess the way I would characterize it is that when you look at the delta between last third quarter and this third quarter for small Commercial, that delta in workers' comp is probably a bit over a point and again that really is coming from the favorability we saw last third quarter. And as I said we were sort of anticipating when we set our loss picks for the year that we would see, like I said about a 0.5 point deterioration. So I think that help size a little bit of just kind of the delta and what we're seeing.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "3eb48752-e893-409f-a429-e4ecb4ee0745", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: And the remainder of that would be property.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "eef844a9-2f8e-42b0-908d-d8ec18d63c46", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Yes.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "13e169f8-8188-422c-9a64-eb5594a4b957", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Great. I appreciate that. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "511a02bd-a38f-4bfb-a215-b36bd25865ed", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yes, thanks. A couple of questions here for you. First I wanted to drill in a little bit in the Middle and Large Commercial Lines underlying combined ratios here. If we take a look, year-to-date are flat and the last couple of quarters have been up year-over-year. Just curious what's kind of surprised you relative to what you were kind of expecting coming into 2022 and what are you doing potentially to address some of those surprises you're seeing in that market or that line?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brian Meredith", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "f866db46-5ec7-4917-961f-8278291ceaaf", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Brian, this is Doug. The only real aberration through either nine months and also in the quarter as our non-CAT, non-weather property volatility, so I look at the rest of the lines, I look at our performance essentially right on target. So that little volatility in the quarter is the only thing we're looking at year-to-date against our expectations.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "d0ffbfb1-b525-40be-89df-9b54009f07f7", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: It -- would inflation may be a little bit higher than you expected and some of the property stuff is that essentially it?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brian Meredith", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "916a1fed-2960-48ae-b30a-a4cac9d40254", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: There's little inflation there, we've talked about inflation, but our pricing has been at or right on expectations as well. So I think, we're matching what we're seeing on the economic loss trend side with our performance on the pricing and so, I feel-good about that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "020c7e66-db17-49dc-8984-22da44595770", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Gotcha. And then within your Global Specialty business, I'm just curious do you all have the capacity or the called desire to potentially take advantage of what could be a much better pricing environment for CAT-exposed property business and what's your appetite for that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brian Meredith", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "a1633f08-ad13-4557-adc0-db8f95f97b8e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: I don't think you're going to see us in the next six months-to become a major CAT rider, right? We don't have that as an ambition, but our growing ambition over the past decade has been to be as stronger, more thoughtful, deeper, bigger property rider and that goal remains and we're doing it selectively. So in our middle and large commercial business, we've got a large property segment, we've got a growing property book and our core middle book and then we also have a really neat specialty business, property business in our Global Specialty so. I look at property across the franchise and I think that on the optimistic side, you will see that grow over-time but, I don't think we're going to step right and try to take advantage of a timing moment right now with CAT property.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "3d88dae0-6773-476b-bc63-baf07a7eee44", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Got you. I appreciate it. Thankyou.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Brian Meredith", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "59d19bd6-739b-41cc-88ae-45abaaf8e1b5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: That's been one of our strategic themes as Doug and I talked about for years just to have a broader property skill set in all our business segments whether it be small, middle or large. E&S and Specialty and then the only of color I would add-on our reinsurance operations is it's a global property-and casualty focus reinsure that has some specialty orientation also to it, rights about all $500 million of total premiums. Doug, I would say it's profitability and execution has been outstanding in the last couple of years. It did obviously suffer some Ian impacts this quarter that we called out, but generally it's a nice specialty orientation in that Global Specialty area.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "14e4fbc0-4057-4594-aa17-9a6068e39054", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Yes, very disciplined, very thoughtful and maybe some selective opportunity here that in Global Re, Brian, they will take advantage of. I was more referring to the primary space, but it's been our strong complement to our property capabilities and our thought process. So I think it'll be opportunistic, We'll be thoughtful about what we do relative to CAT.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "44b3435a-adb1-4de5-a153-5c76dd457938", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Great, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Motemaden", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "f292f600-f320-485c-9a43-adbba5ba3287", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Great, good morning, everyone. I guess for my first question, I'll focus in on the expense ratio. And obviously, there's a broader expense ratio across the entire enterprise, but I was looking at the commercial lines expense ratio. I think it's on Slide 7 and it was 31.5 versus 31.8 a year-ago and I know you've been working on initiatives to improve it. So I guess with the growth that we're seeing, I guess I'm kind of surprised we're not getting a little bit more improvement. So maybe you can unpack what's going on with the expense ratio when -- where the improvements are coming from and the good guys and bad guys, I guess in the expense ratio?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Greg Peters", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "5ed88392-9b95-4e8e-92b5-9c2357654d2e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Brian, let me lay in this context and then [Indecipherable] Beth can add their capabilities. As Beth said in her prepared remarks and you can see in our deck, I'm really pleased with the execution of our Hartford next program over a multi-year. That program and the savings generated is, allowing us to think differently about investing going-forward. And we've maintained sort of our view that we still want to build the organization when certain capabilities areas whether it be digital whether it be APIs. So we still are investing in the organization at a healthy clip that is instead of muting, the underlining efficiencies that we're gaining. And I would call-out the investments we're going to continue to make sort of in our cloud journey as a big initiative over a multiyear period of time, we had large initiatives in Global Specialty over the next couple of years from a data science side and then, lastly from a Group Benefits side, we are going to develop a new administration system with the outside -- with an outside service provider to modernize that 40 year-old tech stack. So I think you know we're builders, we're growers and that's part of why you're seeing maybe less benefit on the expense ratios as we sit here today, but Beth what would you add?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "379f13cd-30a0-4440-9b7f-9e31c482022b", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Yes. I would agree with those comments. I think specifically as it relates to third quarter, I believe in the third quarter of last year, we had a little bit of release and bad debt. So that made last year's number maybe 30 basis-points better so that obviously affects that compare a little bit and then also -- we also look at our commission ratio has kicked up just a small amount as well, which again some of that reflective of just the strong profitability in the book and how that comes through in some of the supplemental comp. So those I think help to explain why maybe wouldn't see more benefit just quarter-over quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "df106b8a-e4f4-4a7c-a886-1bdb2638bad5", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Great. Thanks for the color. I'm gonna pivot and I know you spent time talking about this in your prepared remarks, but on the personal line side, you look at the rate increase trend it's all moving up. I recall travelers comments on their call where they were talking about mid-teens type of rate increases for their book of business next year and I know you have a specialty auto book, but maybe you could spend a little bit more time just telling us how you see the rate trend moving over the next several quarters in the context of all the inflationary pressures we're reading about.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Greg Peters", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "c01fb475-ff4e-426b-91a4-bfed6d90ecd0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Sure, Greg. So maybe I'll build-on what I shared in my script. Again fourth quarter, as I said, we expect that change of five to move our rates move-up into 10 category and then moving to mid-teens. Our expectations in the second-half of the year that our [Indecipherable] them loss trend would abate a bit, did not come to past. So the world we see it today and the trends we're experiencing at this moment, we're expecting those to continue into 2023, which are driving our assumptions inside our rate plan activity. We described the first-half of 2023, an active, great process for us and I think mid-teens will allow us to get on-top of those trends and I expect as we you move through the first-quarter into the second-quarter will be at very adequate terms for our book of business keeping in mind that as we introduce Prevail into the marketplace, which is a six-month policy. We still have lots of policies out there that are 12 months and our old Hartford Auto and Home product is a 12 month products. So there is a mix that will end towards six months the quicker we work our way through Prevail, but at the moment we still have lot of 12-month policies there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "8d673504-679c-4451-9483-2174405883d7", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Greg, it's Chris. You characterized your question as a specialty auto carrier. I would push-back on that, I mean, we consider it a preferred segment, through our AARP relationship over 30 plus years. So maybe, you just -- you have confused thoughts in your head, but it's not a specialty-orientated order book, it is a preferred class of customers at least in my mind.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "840991d4-77d7-4c6c-b9ed-fd5e81966f71", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Right, I understand that one per word choice, but thanks for the additional color and congratulations on your retirement, Doug.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Greg Peters", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "d9f0f087-1234-42e0-953a-9721110f4647", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Raymond James"}

section.text: Thanks, Greg.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "4310945c-e517-4838-a17b-d915c8b12d56", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Hey, good morning. Reading through the press release, you talked about a decrease in new specialty business. Could you share a little color on what lines you're pulling back on and now perhaps what lines you were seeing some strength in new business growth?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "982bdd15-3794-4882-995a-ad4b87f321e9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Andrew, our comments relate to competition in the specialty space, primarily in the professional lines area. So our thin lines area has -- as I commented, seen the press pricing or factor pricing went negative in the second-quarter -- I'm sorry the third quarter for D&O. But it's an area that has gone through significant profit opportunity and now as the lines are very adequate for us and probably many others in the industry, a lot of competition has gathered. So we see that competition, we are not going to chase. For pricing, we're going to keep our discipline and I attribute the lack of growth compared to prior periods in that global specialty space really to competition and us keeping our discipline which we intend to maintain as we move into 2023.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "92a5f412-bb56-488f-a0da-514ed7bc6f12", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: So could you see a further decline in sales of new business?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "4fe90644-fee7-4fac-8315-322a0b156f4e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: So hard to predict and we always give you our best view of the future when we talk to you on the fourth quarter call, but I think the fourth quarter probably will not be a lot different in behavior than what we saw in the third quarter. It's a little early to talk about '23, I think at the moment.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "674844f6-7fab-4029-9c92-7884399f94aa", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Hopeful, Andrew maybe there's a little more rationality that comes back into the market in '23, but time will tell.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "7daae814-1f4a-4a1a-93be-fee0a9b353ad", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Got you. And then shifting back to Personal Lines. It was interesting to me that you cited auto physical damage as a build pressure on the loss ratio, but no mention of the medical cost inflation and I think, Allstate had highlighted some pretty severe movements in there reserving for medical on the auto line. So any thoughts on where medical is trending?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "63c5729c-35e8-4932-82ee-cacffb418a10", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Yeah, so included in our loss picks in auto, a component of that is medical. We have seen some uptick and that's reflected in our estimates and has been in -- we haven't called that out because it hasn't been a significant driver of the changes that we were anticipating for the year, which has really been on the physical damage side because as you recall, we had anticipated to see some relief in inflationary pressures in the second-half that have not obviously materialized.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "402b12f0-cd4d-4cd2-b361-6a1220266dc5", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, maybe if I just sneak one quick one in there. You wrote some new business as you cited in the release in the personal auto where you have given the rate increases that you need, are you comfortable with that new business that you're putting on the books or could that be a little weak in year-one?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "922dba1f-2a28-4b14-b43b-8e9175444bf9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Andrew, good question. We are spending a lot of time on the quality of the new business, we're writing in Personal Lines and I think our team today still feels very solid about the quality, but we are moving on the pricing side and we'll continue to move and it's one of the reasons that we have slowed the Prevail rollout still moving forward, but slowed slightly to make sure that our rate adequacy is as we introduced a new product into market are where they need to be given our view of current trends. And as we've discussed, that trend has been moving on us throughout the year. So, yes, I'm very confident about where we are today and know that quality is something we've got in our front viewfinder day-in, day-out.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 50, "uuid": "efbcbbe2-5894-47bf-a1df-06f1b09cd466", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Thanks a lot.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Andrew Kligerman", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "45ff3814-ff4a-4fa4-8311-7d099f228ba1", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Credit Suisse"}

section.text: Thanks, good morning. I guess, I want to continue with auto for a second. I scratch my head with some auto results for some companies and I got to put yours in that category. I'm little confused on something. And if I look at your auto core results, I mean you've been north of 100 even the back-half of last year, your pricing back then was low-single digits, now five it could be a that's good, it's going to get better. But, I guess what I don't get is your average is north of 100% last year. The question might be just kind of when did you start seeing maybe you saw it differently, when did you start seeing the high physical damage and if you thought a little bit later. But despite north of a 100% and low-single digit pricing even back then, today you're taking favorable development. So I'm confused on that and how long that might last. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Phillips", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "ecb09226-7a54-49d3-9a8e-3b3feefc2699", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yes, Michael, we started seeing adverse [Indecipherable] pressure to our book and our expectations by late -- mid to late-summer last year. So our filings ramped-up in the September timeframe and, they have continued to ramp throughout the year. Many of these states are now in the double-dip stage. So we're taking two bites at that apple inside the year. And our expectation for '22 was that we would see some of those physical damage trends contain themselves a bit in the back-half of the year, which we have not seen over the third quarter. So as we project forward, our activities will deal with the climate we see it today and as such, our fourth quarter pricing activities are going to be in the 10% range that is reflective of where we think those rates need to be filed at and as we continue to '23, as I said it will go north from there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "4e5b543f-d738-402f-8b5b-e5a81ba702f6", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: And then the only thing I add that you did mention the favorable prior year development that we saw in the auto line that was primarily related to 2018 and prior, just to put context on where, we were seeing that benefit.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "0430eaac-36a1-4c44-b5d0-c13db76e8593", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Yes. Okay that's helpful. So it was prior to 2021, but as it is confirmed. Maybe the numbers you have putting up in the back-half of last year had some padding for it despite the fact that as you just said you even start to see the higher trends last year, where you must have put some padding in for 2021 accident year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Phillips", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "46de97d1-f982-415f-9229-71b6642b02ce", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yes, we had increased our views on physical damage in the second half of '21. Again our expectation was that, those were going to start to level-off and we start to see some improvement in the back-half of this year, which obviously we've not seen and we've been responding accordingly each quarter as we book the current quarter activity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "8bb3fb5a-d4d7-4dd8-b3d1-bc2842add64f", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: And Michael, I think it goes without saying, but obviously that activity quarter-by-quarter now is rolling into our filing. So what we experienced in the fourth quarter became a big part of the first and second-quarter filings and the first-quarter so. As we think about the experience we have tried to reflect that -- in our loss pick calls, but also in our filings as we move ahead.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "bef46c09-f7f5-43c0-a2ad-7a578458512a", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, thank you for the clarity. That's all I had. I appreciate it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Phillips", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "7e55f17c-6ab1-4747-ae75-6c30e8983c1f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: Yes, thank you. Looking at the healthy increase in the dividend, I'm just trying to understand the Idea about a permanent 10% increase in the dividend versus extra gunpowder for share repurchase for the lower increase the dividend, how are you balancing, those two things?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Joshua Shanker", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "85abb248-2d05-4141-8cd1-76ea2d7c554f", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Yeah, well. I think we've been consistently balancing those things. We do think that it's important for us to maintain a competitive dividend and I think the dividend really in my mind seeks to just our ongoing earnings power as we see in the organization and as I said kind of path of increasing that each year as our earnings continue to increase. I think we've got a very healthy repurchase authorization that allows us to execute on deploying our excess capital. So, I feel very good about the balance that we create in both of those those items.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "1630dbfb-94da-4b75-992d-96c3ae5fa084", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: And, then I didn't catch it in the prepared remarks, maybe I missed it, but did you give us a gross loss for Ian so we compared to the net loss, how much of reinsurance picked-up.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Joshua Shanker", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "9213374c-42df-4b7a-9993-e3f6196f6534", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: I did not, but I would say that from a reinsurance perspective, it's like $15 million to $16 million of recoverable that we booked within those estimates for Ian loss..
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "95462604-7dbd-46b1-8a4b-99fee9dc03c6", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: That's perfect, thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Joshua Shanker", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "3baa17bf-71a0-400b-945b-b5b1c5dc6ec3", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Thank you. Good morning, everybody and congratulations to Doug on the retirement. I guess first question just with your plan of really keeping the reinsurance structure unchanged next year and I realized, nothing has really set-in stone yet, but assuming you're able to do that and with reinsurance costs probably going up and I think you guys are mostly the admitted markets, so maybe see the ability to offset that through price lag a little bit. I guess all this said, is it reasonable to think that all else equal margins could see a little bit of a low bit of pressure at least in the early half of next year?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Yaron Kinar", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "bd5fa18c-4d60-494f-af17-e7c06bf36e8a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: I think that's a little bit step to take right now. Our property pricing moved up in Middle & Large Commercial toward the end of the third quarter, our underwriters across the franchise on-property know they've got to look hard and ensure to value. Numbers on all of our accounts, I think, they're understanding and looking back at their CAT models given what happens over the last 30 days. So we're moving on the primary side and our experience certainly from a CAT perspective, reinsurance has been generally very, very solid over the last decade. So It is too early to tell, but I'm not thinking about property compression right now. I'm thinking about it in terms of making sure we get needed rate on our book of business across every line that is writing the property.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "91a2516d-bc90-4287-9b13-a21600231e80", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Yaron Kinar", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "7a87c6cb-4ed5-4df4-8915-b63caf51af8a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: I think you said it well, Dough. To me Yaron, it will always think about economics and what does it mean in sort of that risk return trade-off, but as Doug said our historical performance, our deep partnerships with our reinsurers in the fact that we do have multi-year rate guarantees on different layers. I think immunize is a little bit from any pressure on rates that we might face, so time will tell and we'll report back to you early next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "573338e5-7ed2-4dfb-8bb0-56f8cdedf869", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Understood. And then on the D&O competitive pressure commentary, can you maybe add a little more color on where this pressure is coming in more -- is it more in the primary layers, is it more access. you're seeing it more from new entrants or incumbents?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Yaron Kinar", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "e04f9e5e-7322-4ea9-85e1-559ac4ea3716", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Well, I would share, our book is approximately 80% excess in the U.S. D&O space. So, I can comment on what we're seeing there which is -- where the pressure we're seeing -- we're also seeing on the primary side, but our book is primarily excess. So I'd start with that, there have been a series of new entrants over the past 24 months as we all have talked about the IPO market has slowed and the spec market has slowed as well. So the new, new opportunities in the marketplace are not where they were one and two years ago. So lack of upside opportunity and very solid strong rate adequacy has led to quite a bit of competition, which I think is fueling inside this book and assets hitting primarily in our excess area.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "e3e18f9e-782a-4772-a446-88df7a72bdba", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: But I understand that your mostly access, but ultimately if the primary layer is coming in at a lower-price, it also reflects on the access price, I think. So I guess this is more of the pressure coming from the primary layer coming in or is it more from the excess layer pricing diminishing?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Yaron Kinar", "section_number": 73, "uuid": "d1074780-046f-4503-b283-447ffc020b2b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: I think there's pricing pressure up the tower. There is some pressure in the primary, but really speaking to primarily excess where we've seen quite a bit of new capacity come in, easier to come in and the excess area and that's we're experiencing that pressure today.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "c4edec7d-1bdf-494d-b489-f3e36f7a255a", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Got it thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Yaron Kinar", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "1fb49c37-a63b-464e-84d6-193bae3429c4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Jefferies"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Elliot", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "be7171d9-0da1-4a7c-ad76-aa2ceca021ba", "speaker_title": "President at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Thank you, guys. I was just wondering you cited volume-related staffing costs for Commercial, just curious is that, is that related to workers' comp claims or I guess what does that pertain to? I think we had heard about this in group in the past, but not necessarily for P&C.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Ward", "section_number": 78, "uuid": "b5c2334c-cf06-41db-9b92-04655e472c7e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Yes. I would call that more on the production side, not on the claims side. So again as you can see from our very healthy top line from dollars perspective, we also just see some more costs relative to that production just -- which reflects that volume, but not claims related.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 79, "uuid": "34db0047-8f23-41cc-a4c6-528d64f72ae5", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, the rest of my questions were asked. Thank you very much.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Ward", "section_number": 80, "uuid": "3b96e396-10fa-47a8-adb5-357dfaca6970", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Hey, good morning. So first is a set of question on the development in the commercial side. I think you mentioned adverse development in commercial auto. If you could just go into detail on what years are related to and what the driver was?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jimmy Bhullar", "section_number": 82, "uuid": "d299637e-22f3-4203-9054-b3fde80ecd41", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: Yes, so in commercial lines, auto really relates to accident years 2017 to 2019 and specifically we had one claim that had an adverse verdict during the quarter that we reacted to.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Beth Costello", "section_number": 83, "uuid": "c72bcb87-203c-403d-9597-048554fcdf8f", "speaker_title": "Chief Financial Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay. And then on Personal Auto, obviously you're raising prices that will take a while to flow-through your results given your 12-month policies. Do you have any views on states that are not allowing price hikes right now like California and whether the companies are making some sort of headway in convincing regulators to approve price hikes?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jimmy Bhullar", "section_number": 84, "uuid": "36e7c050-6e76-4624-b289-ef9ae3e7e8cd", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: Yes, Jimmy, I'm not going to comment on the regulatory environment because it's pretty dynamic in various parts of the country and you mentioned one particular state. So we pride ourselves on working with all our regulators in a constructive fashion and hopefully that can continue in some of these problematic areas.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Chris Swift", "section_number": 85, "uuid": "5c9e64d4-482e-44e6-bf6a-72a882651f53", "speaker_title": "Chairman & Chief Executive Officer at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

section.text: Okay, that's all I have. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Jimmy Bhullar", "section_number": 86, "uuid": "9915912f-996d-43d8-968a-4fd813a5e3a8", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: Thank you all for joining us today and as always, please reach out with any additional questions. Have a great day.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Susan Spivak", "section_number": 88, "uuid": "3922fbdf-e6bc-4a16-9e9a-7ad20fb55362", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President of Investor Relations at The Hartford Financial Services Group"}

title: Q&A for HIG (The Hartford Financial Services Group) on 10/28/22 9:00 AM ET
